Product Description: ['From Marvel Studios comes DOCTOR STRANGE, the story of world-famous neurosurgeon Dr. Stephen Strange (Benedict Cumberbatch), whose life changes forever after a horrific car accident renders his hands useless. When traditional medicine fails him, he travels to remote Kamar-Taj in search of a cure, but instead discovers the mystical arts and becomes a powerful sorcerer battling dark forces bent on destroying our reality.']
Average Rating: 4.7

reference_summary:
Charlotte Rampling: The Look
Charlotte Rampling  (Actor),     Angelina Maccarone  (Director)    Rated:    NR    Format: DVD
Movies & TV, Genre for Featured Categories, Documentary
['A biographical study of legendary actress Charlotte Rampling (Babylon A.D., Swimming Pool), told through her own conversations with artist friends and collaborators, including Peter Lindbergh, Paul Auster, and Juergen Teller. Intercut with footage from some of Rampling\'s most famous films, this "self-portrait through others" is a revealing look at one of our most iconic screen stars.']
{'Genre': 'Documentary/Biography, Special Interests', 'Format': 'Multiple Formats, Anamorphic, NTSC, Black & White, Widescreen, Color, Surround Sound', 'Contributor': 'Charlotte Rampling, Angelina Maccarone', 'Language': 'English', 'Number Of Discs': '1', 'Is Discontinued By Manufacturer': 'No', 'MPAA rating': 'NR (Not Rated)', 'Product Dimensions': '0.7 x 7.5 x 5.4 inches; 2.56 Ounces', 'Item model number': '25093537', 'Director': 'Angelina Maccarone', 'Media Format': 'Multiple Formats, Anamorphic, NTSC, Black & White, Widescreen, Color, Surround Sound', 'Run time': '1 hour and 34 minutes', 'Release date': 'April 10, 2012', 'Actors': 'Charlotte Rampling', 'Studio': 'Kino Lorber', 'Country of Origin': 'USA', 'Number of discs': '1'}
Absolutely amazing film. If you are a fan of Charlotte Rampling, you'll love it, of course. But what she has to say has significance far beyond her own life. A must-see.

The Statement
Michael Caine  (Actor),     Tilda Swinton  (Actor),     Norman Jewison  (Director, Producer)    &                   0                  more   Rated:    R    Format: DVD
Movies & TV, Studio Specials, Sony Pictures Home Entertainment, All Sony Pictures Titles
["Veteran actor and two-time Oscar(r) winner Michael Caine stars with Tilda Swinton and Jeremy Northam in THE STATEMENT, a shocking and provoking thriller that delves into a fascinating chapter in modernevents! An ambitious Judge (Swinton) and an exacting Colonel (Jeremy Northam) re-open the sixty-year-old case of Pierre Brossard (Michael Caine), an escaped Nazi collaborator accused of murdering seven Jews. Now an old man living a sheltered life within the Catholic Church, Brossard is also being trailed by mysterious hit men, determined to kill him before he's arrested. When the Church shuts outBrossard to protect their dirty secret, it's a race against time, the government, and the hit men to discover whether justice will prevail or revenge will be served!"]

Thoroughly enjoyed this chase thriller. Good story, complex characters, good acting. The fact that Michael Caine's character wasn't entirely despicabledisturbed many viewers when the film was released, so it wasn't a hit at the box office and received some poor reviews. They should take another look now.
Thoroughly enjoyed this chase thriller
45 Years
Charlotte Rampling  (Actor),     Tom Courtenay  (Actor),     Andrew Haigh  (Director)    &                   0                  more   Rated:    R    Format: DVD
Movies & TV, Paramount Home Entertainment, Drama
['Award-winning actors Charlotte Rampling (Swimming Pool) and Tom Courtenay (Doctor Zhviago) give career-defining performances in 45 Years. As Kate and Geoff prepare to celebrate their 45th wedding anniversary, their marriage is shaken when unexpected news threatens to change their lives. The body of his first love has been discovered, frozen and preserved in the icy glaciers of the Swiss Alps. By the time the party is upon them, five days later, there may not be a marriage left to celebrate.']
{'Genre': 'Drama', 'Format': 'NTSC', 'Contributor': 'Charlotte Rampling, Andrew Haigh, Tom Courtenay, Geraldine James', 'Language': 'English', 'Is Discontinued By Manufacturer': 'No', 'MPAA rating': 'R (Restricted)', 'Product Dimensions': '0.7 x 7.5 x 5.4 inches; 2.72 Ounces', 'Item model number': '35375576', 'Director': 'Andrew Haigh', 'Media Format': 'NTSC', 'Release date': 'June 14, 2016', 'Actors': 'Charlotte Rampling, Tom Courtenay, Geraldine James', 'Studio': 'Paramount', 'Number of discs': '1'}
An exceptional film. If you cannot appreciate the small movements and the subtleties of changes in facial expressions, you will fail to see what an amazing film this is. Charlotte Rampling at her very best...so far.
you will fail to see what an amazing film this is
The Lives of Others
Martina Gedeck  (Actor),     Ulrich Mühe  (Actor),     Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck  (Director)    &                   0                  more   Rated:    R    Format: DVD
Movies & TV, Studio Specials, Sony Pictures Home Entertainment, Sony Pictures Classics, Drama
['Product Description', 'This critically-acclaimed, Oscar®-winning film (Best Foreign Language Film, 2006) is the erotic, emotionally-charged experience Lisa Schwarzbaum (Entertainment Weekly) calls "a nail-biter of a thriller!" Before the collapse of the Berlin Wall, East Germany\x92s population was closely monitored by the State Secret Police (Stasi). Only a few citizens above suspicion, like renowned pro-Socialist playwright Georg Dreyman, were permitted to lead private lives. But when a corrupt government official falls for Georg\x92s stunning actress-girlfriend, Christa, an ambitious Stasi policeman is ordered to bug the writer\x92s apartment to gain incriminating evidence against the rival. Now, what the officer discovers is about to dramatically change their lives - as well as his - in this seductive political thriller Peter Travers (Rolling Stone) proclaims is "the best kind of movie: one you can\x92t get out of your head."', 'Amazon.com', "Nominated for a Best Foreign Language Film Oscar, this is a first-rate thriller that, like Bertolucci's", 'The Conformist', "and Coppola's", 'The Conversation', ', opts for character development over car chases. The place is East Berlin, the year is 1984, and it all begins with a simple surveillance assignment: Capt. Gerd Wiesler (Ulrich Mühe in a restrained, yet deeply felt performance), a Stasi officer and a specialist in this kind of thing, has been assigned to keep an eye on Georg Dreyman (Sebastian Koch,', 'Black Book', '), a respected playwright, and his actress girlfriend, Christa-Maria Sieland (Martina Gedeck,', 'Mostly Martha', "). Though Dreyman is known to associate with the occasional dissident, like blacklisted director Albert Jerska (Volkmar Kleinert), his record is spotless. Everything changes when Wiesler discovers that Minister Hempf (Thomas Thieme) has an ulterior motive in spying on this seemingly upright citizen. In other words, it's personal, and Wiesler's sympathies shift from the government to its people--or at least to this one particular person. That would be risky enough, but then Wiesler uses his privileged position to affect a change in Dreyman's life. The God-like move he makes may be minor and untraceable, but it will have major consequences for all concerned, including Wiesler himself. Writer/director Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck starts with a simple premise that becomes more complicated and emotionally involving as his assured debut unfolds. Though three epilogues is, arguably, two too many,", 'The Lives of Others', "is always elegant, never confusing. It's class with feeling. --", 'Kathleen C. Fennessy', 'Beyond', 'The Lives of Others', 'Films from Germany', 'Other Cold War Films', 'More Arthouse Selections from Sony Pictures Classics', 'Stills from', 'The Lives of Others', '(click for larger image)']
{'Genre': 'Mystery & Thrillers', 'Format': 'AC-3, Color, Dolby, Widescreen, Subtitled, NTSC', 'Contributor': 'Ulrich Tukur, Thomas Thieme, Hans-Uwe Bauer, Ulrich Mühe, Sebastian Koch, Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck, Charly Hübner, Volkmar Kleinert, Matthias Brenner, Herbert Knaup, Martina GedeckUlrich Tukur, Thomas Thieme, Hans-Uwe Bauer, Ulrich Mühe, Sebastian Koch, Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck, Charly Hübner, Volkmar Kleinert, Matthias Brenner, Herbert Knaup, Martina Gedeck  See more', 'Language': 'German (Dolby Digital 5.1), Unqualified', 'Runtime': '2 hours and 18 minutes', 'Aspect Ratio': '2.35:1', 'Is Discontinued By Manufacturer': 'No', 'MPAA rating': 'R (Restricted)', 'Product Dimensions': '7.5 x 5.5 x 0.5 inches; 2.4 Ounces', 'Director': 'Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck', 'Media Format': 'AC-3, Color, Dolby, Widescreen, Subtitled, NTSC', 'Run time': '2 hours and 18 minutes', 'Release date': 'August 21, 2007', 'Actors': 'Martina Gedeck, Ulrich Mühe, Sebastian Koch, Ulrich Tukur, Thomas Thieme', 'Subtitles': 'English, Spanish, French', 'Studio': 'Sony Pictures', 'Number of discs': '1'}
A film that can change your life. In German, with excellent English subtitles. Every prop historically accurate. Even the color scheme and lighting contribute. Contrary to how it's billed in the popular press, this is not a sensual romance. It's about...redemption. See it!
with excellent English subtitles

profile:
The user exhibits a strong preference for documentary and biographical films, particularly those centered around significant cultural figures, alongside a recent trend toward engaging with superhero narratives featuring complex storytelling and character development. Their latest five-star rating reflects an appreciation for nuanced performances, indicating a taste for emotionally compelling narratives that resonate deeply. 

This interaction reveals an expanding cinematic interest that encompasses not only intellectually rich dramas but also mainstream action films that deliver high production quality and significant character arcs. The user's previous affinity for films with profound themes of human experience and redemption remains steadfast, now complemented by an enjoyment of visually dynamic stories where character development and moral dilemmas play critical roles. 

Their profile showcases an evolving yet consistent pattern, characterized by an alignment for emotionally resonant narratives, complex characters, and films that invite reflection. Key themes in their cinematic choices include poignant storytelling, emotional depth, and intellectual engagement, alongside an exploration of diverse genres such as documentaries, biographical films, gripping dramas, and now select action-adventure films. This indicates a broadening appreciation for entertainment that balances visual spectacle with significant narrative depth.
